prompt_final.content: You are an expert in sustainable development education with a focus on the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Your task is to identify only the SDGs that are directly and explicitly addressed by a university course module, based on the provided module title, learning outcomes, and course content descriptions. When assigning the SDGs follow the following steps in the given order: 1. Direct Relevance: SDGs must be clearly and explicitly relevant based on the exact terms, topics, or concepts mentioned in (a) Module Title, (b) Learning Outcomes, (c) Course Content. 1.a Module Title: Look for explicit SDG themes in the module title ("titelde", "titelen"). 1.b Learning Outcomes: Examine specific learning objectives or skills listed for the module to identify SDG priorities ("lernergebnissede", "lernergebnisseen"). 1.c Course Content: Analyze the listed topics and themes to match them to SDGs ("lerninhaletde", "lerninhalteen"). 2. Indirect Relevance: In cases where direct relevance cannot be established, consider indirect relevance by evaluating broader impacts. However, prioritize SDGs that align most closely with the module"s explicit focus and avoid speculative connections. 2.a Module Title: Reflect on the broader themes and implications of the module title that might relate to SDGs, even if not explicitly mentioned. 2.b Learning Outcomes: Analyze the learning outcomes for potential impacts on sustainable development goals, even if the connection is not directly stated. 2.c Course Content: Evaluate the course content for topics that might have indirect relevance to SDGs, considering the broader context and potential applications of the material. 3. Prioritization: If a module could be assigned to multiple SDGs, focus on the most directly relevant ones. Do not include SDGs that are only indirectly addressed or require significant interpretation beyond the explicit information provided. 4. Source Identification: For each assigned SDG, clearly indicate the step (a. Module Title, b. Learning Outcomes, c. Course Content) where the connection was identified first. 5. Explanation: After assigning the SDGs, provide a concise explanation for all the selected SDGs, clearly describing how the provided descriptions align explicitly with each SDG. Based on the provided information, including the module title, learning outcomes, and course content, assign only the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are directly and explicitly relevant to the module. For each SDG, clearly indicate where the decision to assign it was made by referencing one of the following steps: (a) Module Title, (b) Learning Outcomes, or (c) Course Content. Additionally, provide a concise explanation for all selected SDGs, describing how the provided descriptions explicitly align with the SDG framework. Ensure your response is structured to include the SDGs with step identification, followed by a brief explanation that justifies your choices based on the information provided. When explaining SDG choices, use the following structure: SDG Number (Step): Brief reason for inclusion.

For the module with the Module Title: Energy Entrepreneurship, the Learning Outcomes: The course "Energy Entrepreneurship in Developing Countries" aims to teach students how the combination of entrepreneurship with sustainable and renewable energy technologies can have a positive impact on the development of low-income communities in the global South. The course provides a learning and exchange platform for students with business and/or technical knowledge and interest in understanding and starting energy-related businesses in the Global South and exploring the various thematic areas of energy access. The aim is to jointly promote exchange and discussion, generate new ideas, develop skills and learning tools to plan a viable business idea and improve the opportunities to access energy in the Global South. During the lecture, the participants will have the opportunity to develop their own business idea and to create a business plan. An alternative is to prepare a seminar paper with the methods learned on applied energy economics. After completing this course, students will be able to independently handle science- and business-related topics in the field of energy economics, especially energy access and environmental as well as sustainability policy. Based on the preparation and presentation of current case studies and publications, the students acquire presentation skills as well as the handling complex activities in the context of group work, discussions, generating business ideas and starting a new business. and the Course Content: The lecture "Entrepreneurship" and "Energy in Developing Countries" offers a mixture of theoretically oriented lectures, guest speakers from the practice as well as practical (group) work, which aims at the development and evaluation of entrepreneurial basics and the elaboration of own potential entrepreneurial ventures or business ideas. The main topics and learning contents are • Understanding the relationship between energy access and economic development • Overview of the most important approaches to rural electrification and understanding of the "Energy Ladder” framework • Assessment of possible business ideas and entrepreneurial initiatives in the context of the development problems of the Global South • Insight into a multitude of practical examples of "Social Entrepreneurship" and Organizational Models: social entrepreneurship in the area of conflict between profit orientation, social impact, sustainability and innovation • Identification and consideration of specific local customer needs • Design of a business model and strategy • Building a successful team and implementing a business venture • Creating a start-up idea and business plan, with final presentation (Start-Up Pitch) • Seminar paper on relevant related topics to explore the learned methods according to a concrete case study

For the module with the Module Title: Wastewater drainage and treatment - Urban water management II, the Learning Outcomes: Graduates: - have an in-depth understanding of wastewater technology systems and can plan and dimension important plant components, - have mastered the basic calculation methods so that graduates can later independently follow changes in the state of the art and the rules of technology, - have the ability to investigate and evaluate new and emerging technologies, - can work independently in a scientific manner. The course teaches: 40% knowledge and understanding 20% development and design 20% research and evaluation 20% application and practice and the Course Content: Lecture: - Function, planning and calculation of wastewater technology systems and processes - Design and layout of sewerage systems and their structures, wastewater treatment, stormwater treatment and the treatment of sewage sludge and residual materials Calculation exercise: The exercise part of this course deals with practical calculation examples. For example: - Calculation of sewerage networks - Biological and advanced wastewater treatment - Stormwater treatment plants (overflows, overflow basins, retention areas, infiltration) - Sludge treatment plants

For the module with the Module Title: EU health policy, the Learning Outcomes: Participants have an overview of both the competences of the EU with regard to various aspects of healthcare and the bodies involved and deepen their knowledge in an area of their choice. They can discuss related topics and formulate and defend their own opinions in the group. and the Course Content: Health policy is becoming increasingly important within the European Union. According to Article 168 (7) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), responsibility for health policy and the organisation of healthcare and medical care for European citizens lies with the Member States; the EU healthcare system is therefore not harmonised. However, the EU does intervene in healthcare systems through, among other things, labour, competition and internal market law, and from 2013 through the ‘Directive on the application of patients’ rights in cross-border healthcare’. As a result, the EU mandate with regard to health is now quite far-reaching. Building on this theoretical background, the seminar will first provide an overview of EU competences regarding various aspects of healthcare. Individual aspects (reimbursement for rare diseases, inpatient care in border regions, the European Health Card, medicinal products and market access via the EMA, EU-wide examinations for healthcare professionals, EU-wide quality indicators, choice of healthcare insurer) will be explored in greater depth in the block seminar and on the basis of group work. 
During the seminar, participants will be expected to ask further questions, contribute to the lecturers‘ questions and express their own knowledge and opinions in the group (’active oral participation"). Participants will continue to work on case studies by commenting on (fictitious) proposed changes to the Directive on the application of patients' rights in cross-border healthcare from the perspective of a given EU country. The aim is to present this opinion to the group and to work out a draft proposal in a plenary discussion on which all countries can agree. Students should be able to represent the interests of the given country as well as chair the plenary discussion for one of the case studies. Active oral participation (see above) is also expected.

For the module with the Module Title: Applications of industrial information technology, the Learning Outcomes: The product world is becoming increasingly complex and the repertoire of skills that engineers need to have is growing daily, with the sustainability of products and development processes playing a particularly important role. This course is designed to enable students to learn how to deal with complex industry-related project tasks and sustainable development methods. Using information technology solutions in an industrial environment, the project task is implemented in a goal-oriented and resource-saving manner. Both theoretical and practical knowledge of the company-wide integration and development of processes along the value chain will be acquired. The focus here will be on sustainability and how it can and should be taken into account in the development of products or product-service systems from the outset. and the Course Content: For the application of information technology in the industrial environment, the course provides knowledge on the topics of product development processes and process management in terms of sustainable development, as well as systems engineering and e-business. On the other hand, students are introduced to systems for product data management (with variant management, complexity management and change management) and computer-aided design with CAD systems (computer-aided design) as well as an introduction to the digital twin. As part of the exercise, students work in small interdisciplinary groups with the module ‘Development and Management of Digital Product Creation Processes’ on a practice-oriented problem, which is posed by real people, for example, as part of the internal MatchMyMaker cooperation within the department. Students on the ‘Applications of Industrial Information Technology’ module are responsible for project planning and implementation, as well as the development of a technical product service system based on sustainable criteria, from the initial idea to the physical prototype. The tasks to be carried out include Creation of product ideas, implementation of concepts in CAD, creation of a digital twin, selection of materials and components, production planning, creation of a programme code, etc.

For the module with the Module Title: Gas dynamics I, the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the Gas Dynamics I module, students will have: knowledge - of basic concepts of gas dynamics - in dealing with state variables under different flow boundary conditions - of outflow processes from pressure accumulators - of compression shocks and expansions - of the interaction of shocks and expansion waves - of flow states in and behind convergent nozzles or Laval nozzles - of unsteady wave propagation according to acoustic theory - of unsteady wave propagation in shock wave tubes - of different experimental facilities for investigating gas dynamics issues Skills: - Calculation of outflow processes from pressure accumulators with regard to the state variable curve, the mass flow and the resulting momentum (thrust) for different nozzle contours - Calculation of the change in state variables for frictionless or adiabatic pipe flows - Calculation of the change in flow variables via oblique and vertical compression shocks - Calculation of the change in flow variables via the expansions occurring at convex corners - Calculation of the changes in flow variables in the case of complex shock-impact-impact-expansion or expansion-expansion interferences Calculation of state variable progression in Laval nozzles - Calculation of state variables behind non-matched Laval nozzles - Creation of wave plans for acoustic wave propagation as well as in shock wave tubes Skills: - Design of pressure storage channels - Design of profiles for supersonic flows - Evaluation of the properties of Laval nozzles depending on their area of application - Programming and presentation of results using Python or Matlab software - Working in small groups and the Course Content: Lecture: - Thermodynamic fundamentals of gas dynamics - Stationary, one-dimensional compressible flows - Compressible flows with friction and heat exchange - Compression shocks - Isentropic compression and expansion flows - Quasi-one-dimensional flows - Unsteady wave propagation - Experimental facilities Exercise: - Fundamentals: Differentiation from aerodynamics, definitions of internal energy, enthalpy and entropy, conservation laws, gas equation, changes of state - Calculation methods: Derivation and application of the equations according to de Saint-Vernant & Wantzel (outflow formula), area-velocity relationship, area-mach number relationship, flow rate, mass flow - Calculation methods: Calculation of frictionless pipe flows (Rayleigh flows) or adiabatic pipe flows (Fanno flows) - Shocks: The phenomena of shock and oblique shock are discussed using typical supersonic configurations, application of heart curves to shock reflections, shock polars, discussion of shock crossings, development of the Rayleigh-Pitot equation and its comparison with isentropic relationships, calculation of tail flows - Compression and expansion flows: Development of the Prandtl-Meyer corner expansion and application to typical supersonic configurations, calculation and discussion of pressure curves on supersonic profiles - quasi-one-dimensional flows: Calculation of state variables in and behind matched or unmatched Laval nozzles, discussion of different operating states of Laval nozzles considering mass flow, thrust development of convergent or transient wave propagation: application of acoustic theory, calculation of the propagation of compression and expansion waves, calculation of the operating states of shock wave tubes, creation of wave plans for closed and open shock tubes Experiment: The following experiment is carried out in small groups at the trans/supersonic channel of the Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics: Measurement of a biconvex profile in supersonic, calculation of the pressure coefficient, discussion of the phenomena of shock and expansion using the Schlieren method

For the module with the Module Title: Analysis and evaluation of transportation systems, the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the module, students have knowledge and skills in the analysis of transport systems, evaluation procedures in transport planning and the transport policy decision-making process. and the Course Content: This course presents economic concepts, theories and methods that allow the causes and consequences of transport to be analysed and transport policy instruments and measures to be assessed. Economic and transport planning aspects are combined. The following topics form the focus of the course: - Transport supply and demand - Pricing and transport markets - Allocation of resources and opportunity costs - (Natural) monopoly and regulation - External effects and internalisation - Welfare theory - Monetisation of benefits - Problems of benefit measurement and aggregability - Federal Transport Infrastructure Plan (principles, methods, preparation) - Various evaluation methods: Benefit-cost analysis (focus), utility analysis, effectiveness analysis The module contains topics according to §44 para. 3 AllgStuPO to the extent of 2 CP.

For the module with the Module Title: Smart Sensing, the Learning Outcomes: After taking this course, students will be able to outline and discuss the latest advances on digital measurement techniques in the broad field of critical urban infrastructure. These include water flow/pressure metering, IoT (Internet of Things) sensors for water and energy applications, simulation of virtual sensors and sensor networks architectures, and processing of sensor data. The technical content on new digital technologies will be coupled with content on the relevance of smart sensing techniques for better monitoring and resilience of interconnected critical urban infrastructure (e.g., water networks, electricity grid, sensor networks). The students will learn what the current research challenges in the field of digital metering are, in different scientific settings. Students will also be able to apply qualitative and quantitative techniques of systematically analysing, summarizing and presenting scientific data and articles. They will then be able to approach the practical implementation of solutions to currently relevant problems in the field of digitalisation of critical urban infrastructure in the “Smart City Hackathon”. and the Course Content: The course content is divided into three thematic clusters: 1) Urban Context and associated opportunities and challenges 2) Conceptual and practical tools of innovation 3) Scientific communication and methodology Across these three areas, the block course “Smart Sensing” deals with the area of sensors, data gathering and processing in different urban critical infrastructure sectors. Moreover, it will give fundamental knowledge about data harvesting and processing (e.g., with new digital sensors and IoT technologies). In this course, the digitalization of urban critical infrastructure will be analysed, with a particular focus on its sensor components and applications. Assessment will include a presentation, the creation of a wiki page and an online quiz. The course will be given in English.

For the module with the Module Title: Airport planning, the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the Airport Planning module, students will have: Knowledge of - relevant legal regulations (international, European, national) - boundary conditions of new and expansion projects - aspects of master planning - basics of flight procedure determination - lighting and marking of taxiways and aprons - ground handling processes - terminal concepts - processes of various logistics chains (passengers, baggage, cargo) - landside connectivity options, Modal split - Environmental and noise effects Skills - Capacity calculation of airport elements - Forecast calculation and application of various methods - Obstacle analysis according to ICAO Annex 14 - Design of runways, taxiways and aprons - Determination of the space requirements of a terminal and design of terminal facilities - Creation of a landside traffic concept - Creation of an environmental concept and planning of compensation measures - Communication between different participants in a project - Simple project management strategies Skills: - Working with international/supranational/national regulations - Understanding the various interests involved in airport expansion and new construction - Application of planning methods - Solving complex planning tasks - Working in small groups as part of an overall project - Using a CAD program - Presentation techniques - Scientific work and the Course Content: General overview of airports worldwide General design and new construction planning Capacity analysis and calculation of airside and landside elements Fundamentals and criteria of flight procedure planning Obstacle analysis Design of runway system Design of other movement areas Design and basic concept of the terminal and terminal facilities Design and basic concept of landside connection Environmental impacts and associated compensatory and countermeasures International, supranational and national legal framework Project task: - Development of a master plan for an airport Furthermore, excursions and guest lectures are offered as part of the course.

For the module with the Module Title: Sociology of technology and innovation, the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the module, students have in-depth knowledge of central theoretical approaches and empirical findings in social science technology and innovation research and are able to apply this knowledge to the analysis of innovation processes. The module predominantly teaches professional competence 30 % methodological competence 10 % system competence 30 % social competence 30 % and the Course Content: The module offers an in-depth examination of central theoretical approaches and empirical findings in social science technology and innovation research. This includes an examination of theoretical developments and theoretical controversies that have characterised the field of social science technology and innovation research, as well as the question of possible changes in processes of technology development and innovation itself.

For the module with the Module Title: Urban and Spatial Sociology (MA Sociology), the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the module, students will have deepened their knowledge of spatial and urban sociological theories. They will have acquired the skills required to carry out their own research project in the subject area. They will have reflected on the situated nature of knowledge and will be able to think about sociology in global terms. They will have reflected on the conceptual challenges of a relational spatial sociological perspective. They have expanded their competence in conducting a scientific discussion. They deepened their ability to reflect and trained their sociological argumentation skills. In addition, students gained experience in the conception of research projects. and the Course Content: The module deepens knowledge of urban and spatial sociology. Building on relational spatial knowledge, which was either acquired in the BA or acquired in self-study at the beginning of the course, sociological spatial thinking and research is deepened in the module. To this end, current and systematic texts are discussed together and discussions are held with researchers from the field of urban and spatial sociology on current issues. In line with the basic idea of spatial relationality, cultural comparisons, global relationships and hybrid, urban spatial constructions are at the centre of the joint analyses. Participants develop their own research ideas in the module. On the basis of the knowledge of studies and theories acquired in the module, a detailed exposé for their own research project is developed. The content of the module for the MA programme is linked to relevant research activities in the fields of planning and architectural sociology and spatial sociology, so that students can gain a precise impression of these fields of work. The courses in the module are dedicated to current research developments, which is why the titles of individual courses vary. Aspects of gender, diversity, social and global inequality as well as social, ecological and economic sustainability are always discussed.

For the module with the Module Title: Energy Economics - Energy and Resource Policy (EW-POL) , the Learning Outcomes: Students acquire basic knowledge of the energy system, the energy sources and technologies used to generate electricity and heat and the associated environmental protection and CO2 reduction technologies. Methodical knowledge is taught in the analysis of energy markets and energy policies and applied by the students using examples in the course. Students will gain an understanding of current developments in German energy policy resulting from changing economic conditions and the international climate agreement. Students will also be able to fundamentally evaluate energy policy measures. By preparing and presenting current scientific publications, students will acquire presentation skills and practise working with scientific literature. In addition, the teaching of the course content is supported by a specialist excursion and external speakers. and the Course Content: The study of the energy industry and energy policy is divided into economic, commercial, technical, legal, ecological and social issues arising from the special features of the individual energy sources and the associated markets and regulatory models. The focus of the event is on the current challenges for policy makers due to the changes in the energy market resulting from Germany's commitments to climate protection. In particular, the event will cover the following topics: the individual energy sources and the specifics of the associated markets and policies, including market failures, regulation of energy markets, energy technologies, innovation in general and in the energy sector, negative externalities in energy supply and their internalization. In addition, special areas such as energy efficiency, the promotion of renewable energies and the forecast of the development of the energy industry are covered.

For the module with the Module Title: Environmental-economic problems of water management, the Learning Outcomes: The aim of the course is to enable students to independently develop and present the interdependent interactions of the water cycle and water economics. and the Course Content: The course focuses on environmental and industrial economic problems of water management. Overall, the course is problem-orientated, but requires a willingness to take a close look at the theoretical and methodological foundations of the water policy debate. A graded assessment will take place at the end of the semester in the form of a written examination and the assessment of exercises that can be completed during the semester. Topics of the course: - Some basics of resource economics: water cycle, scarcity aspects, groundwater management, water transfer - Some basics of industrial economics: natural monopoly, cost subadditivities, cross-subsidisation, economies of scope, reversible/irreversible costs, universal services - Pricing policy: Universal service providers, price discrimination, peak load tariffs, block tariffs - Theory of regulation: RoR regulation, price caps, incentive regulation, yardstick competition, benchmarking - Sustainability and integrated water management: European Water Framework Directive, river basin management, equity aspects

For the module with the Module Title: Chemistry and physics of the atmosphere, the Learning Outcomes: The students - know the structure, composition and essential physical and chemical processes of the atmosphere, - have the ability to quantitatively describe atmospheric chemical interactions and to estimate their significance for the transformation, transport and deposition of substances, - can assess the behavior and significance of important atmospheric trace substances and atmospheric aerosols for climate, health and the environment, - have teamwork and problem-solving skills. The course teaches: 40 % knowledge and understanding, 20 % analysis and methodology, 20 % research and evaluation, 20 % application and practice and the Course Content: - Atmosphere: structure and properties - Chemistry of the stratosphere and troposphere: oxidation reactions - Transport in the atmosphere: long-distance transport, atmospheric stability, wet/dry deposition - Atmospheric aerosol: fundamentals, physical properties, particle movement, chemical composition, thermodynamics - Clouds and precipitation: droplet formation, reactions in droplets and on surfaces, liquid-phase chemistry - Multiphase chemistry: formation of atmospheric particles and growth, phase transition - Quantitative description and modelling of atmospheric processes

For the module with the Module Title: Pollutants in soil and landscape, the Learning Outcomes: Due to their filter, buffer and transformation potential, soils are of outstanding importance for the dynamics of pollutants in the environment. However, this potential is limited and endangered. Students learn to understand this central role of soils in the landscape and should be able to recognize soil hazards. In addition, knowledge of the necessary soil measurement techniques and basic knowledge of remediation strategies for contaminated soils are taught. On the basis of this module, methods can be developed for recording pollutant contamination in soils and for remediating soils. The course mainly teaches: technical competence 40%; methodological competence 30%; system competence 25%; social competence 5%. and the Course Content: A two-hour integrated course (IV) provides basic knowledge about pollutants in soils and landscapes. - Fundamentals of anthropogenic pollution of soils - Soils as a source and sink of pollutants - Effects of nutrient inputs on soil functions - Heavy metals and organic pollutants in the landscape - Measures for protection and recultivation A practical part of the module consists of a one-day excursion to a field trial and a soil chemistry laboratory practical course to record soil pollution.

For the module with the Module Title: Water quality, the Learning Outcomes: The students: - have in-depth knowledge of the scientific principles of water pollution control and understand the physical, chemical and biological processes in water bodies and in water treatment and wastewater treatment, - are proficient in the methods of water chemistry calculations and the use of the “MINEQL” software The course teaches: 40% knowledge and understanding, 20% development and design, 20% research and evaluation, 20% application and practice and the Course Content: In-depth treatment of physical, chemical and biological processes in bodies of water, in wastewater treatment and in water treatment: quantitative description, kinetics, applications

For the module with the Module Title: Life cycle assessments, the Learning Outcomes: be able to master the method of life cycle assessment for quantifying the environmental impact of a product system, taking into account the entire product life cycle, and transfer this scientific knowledge to practice, -have the ability to clearly define the objective and scope of the life cycle assessment (LCA) as a function of the question and the relevance of the result, -have a scientific understanding of how to deal with large model systems, the dependencies and interactions of the system elements among each other and those of the systems with each other, and -think in terms of systems. be able to analyze and solve methodical and technical problems in the exercise through the acquired knowledge and discussions in a team. The course teaches: 40 % knowledge and understanding, 20 % development & design, 20 % research & evaluation, 10 % application & practice, 10 % social skills and the Course Content: -Phases and components of the life cycle assessment -Prerequisites, possibilities and limitations of the method, procedure of ISO 14040/14044 - Aspects of system analysis for the life cycle inventory: target definition, scope of investigation, equality of benefits, functional unit, reference flow, system elements, data quality, process and system modelling, system boundaries and cut-off criteria, elementary flows, allocation, system expansion, calculation of the overall system - Basics of life cycle impact assessment: Global, regional and local impact categories, characterisation models and factors, impact indicators and endpoints, standardisation, ordering and weighting -Basics of evaluation (LC Interpretation): Methods of screening, utility, effectiveness, error, sensitivity, consistency and completeness analyses, conclusions, system contexts for evaluating conclusions

For the module with the Module Title: Radiation protection, the Learning Outcomes: The students: - have comprehensive knowledge of the handling of radioactive substances, - know the properties and interaction processes of ionizing radiation and have knowledge of radiation protection technology, - are able to grasp the topics of scientific principles, technology and law in a networked manner for the optimal achievement of protection goals with regard to people and the environment, - are able to implement concrete protective measures for different uses and effects of ionizing radiation, - have application-oriented knowledge through practicals and excursions. By successfully completing this module, students also acquire the specialist knowledge as an additional qualification with which they can later apply to the State Office for Occupational Safety, Health Protection and Technical Safety (LAGetSi) for specialist knowledge in radiation protection (according to S2.1, S2.2, S4.1 and S4.2). The course teaches: 40 % knowledge and understanding, 20 % development and design, 20 % research and evaluation, 20 % application and practice and the Course Content: Different types of ionizing radiation, their origin, their distribution and their relevance from a physical point of view, national and international legal framework conditions for radiation protection, measurements of the relevant types of radiation and equipment options for protection against this radiation

For the module with the Module Title: Food analysis, the Learning Outcomes: Students acquire knowledge of the fundamentals, procedures and methods of traditional and modern food analysis. This includes both wet-chemical and instrumental methods. The course teaches: 60% knowledge & understanding 20% analysis & methodology 10% development and design 10% application & practice and the Course Content: Chemical and physical principles of analysis; wet-chemical as well as instrumental methods for the determination of the various food ingredients; mathematical and bininformative methods for the evaluation and assessment of analysis results.

For the module with the Module Title: Quality management, food law and statistics, the Learning Outcomes: Students should: 1. understand the basic elements of internal quality management and quality assurance 2. have knowledge of food law and its structure in the EU and Germany 3. have knowledge of systems to ensure the quality and safety of the food chain and be able to define risk characteristics and explain the basics of the Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) system 4. have knowledge of the implementation of certifications and audits in the company 5. Apply the concepts of statistics to effectively plan experiments and set up statistical models for process relationships 6. Assess the suitability of statistical methods for solving quality-related tasks (e.g. reducing the error rate in production, increasing product life) 7. Explain how analytical and graphical statistical methods work to evaluate data on products and processes 8. Independently apply typical quality and nutrition-related tasks using statistical methods The course teaches: 50% knowledge & understanding 50% application & practice and the Course Content: Quality management area - Basic aspects of quality management: management methods, quality planning methods (e.g. HACCP, FMEA, QFD), basics of documentation and hygiene management - Internal core processes in industrial food processing and related questions on the structure of operational quality management are discussed. This includes the organisation of quality assurance measures, possibilities for quality improvement, their statistical planning and evaluation as well as complaint and crisis management. - Independent design and presentation of the relevant concepts and elements using case studies - Discussion of the possibilities of external assessment of quality management systems (e.g. International Food Standard, ISO 9000ff.) and analysis of cross-level QM systems. Area of food law - Food law principles of quality management in the EU and in Germany are presented. This includes, for example, the principles of food law: placing on the market, commercial practice, consumer expectation, prohibition principle with reservation of permission, guiding principles of the German Food Code, Food and Feed Code (LFGB) as well as questions of due diligence and liability, the structure of food monitoring, administrative offences and criminal proceedings. - Special aspects of food law include: hygiene law (e.g. hygiene package, Infection Protection Act, staff training) and food labelling Statistics - familiarisation with the basic statistical methods for describing data from a sample: classification of characteristics, determination of frequency distributions and suitable measures of location and dispersion and graphics (e.g. histogram, box whisker plot, symmetry plot, etc.) - description of relationships between two or more characteristics using correlation coefficients and expression of their form using equations of regression analysis Description of relationships between two and more characteristics using correlation coefficients and expression of their form using equations of regression analysis - Relationship between sample and population in the context of probability theory: random event, probability, random variable, point and interval estimators, confidence intervals, distribution function binomial distribution and normal distribution - Introduction to the inferential methods of statistics (hypothesis tests and variance analysis) as well as the interaction of descriptive and inferential methods using numerous examples from the food sector

For the module with the Module Title: Biochemistry of nutrition, the Learning Outcomes: Students should be able to explain and interpret the following basic processes of nutritional biochemistry: - Absorption and distribution of nutrients in the body - Metabolism of the main food components - Hormonal control of metabolism The course predominantly teaches: 80% knowledge and understanding 20% analysis and methodology 0% application and practice and the Course Content: Characteristics of living systems Structure and function of biological membranes - Molecular and structural composition of membranes - Substance exchange through the biological membrane - Membrane receptors - Structural organisation of cells - Cell compartmentation - Function of cell organelles - Uptake and distribution of nutrients in the body - Structure of the gastrointestinal tract - Uptake, digestion and absorption of the most important food components in the gastrointestinal tract

For the module with the Module Title: Image-based blood flow simulation of the human circulatory system, the Learning Outcomes: Participants will learn how patient-specific blood flow simulations can be carried out on the basis of medical image data in order to support doctors in therapy decisions. They will acquire knowledge in the segmentation of blood vessels, literature analysis, mathematical blood flow simulation and the use of software for numerical flow simulation. and the Course Content: Medical issues: risk of vascular pathologies such as aneurysms or stenoses, extraction of blood vessel models from medical image data, parameterisation of flow simulations

For the module with the Module Title: Medical technology in hospitals, the Learning Outcomes: Graduates of this module learn the necessary basics of the engineer working in the medical technology department of a hospital in the application of medical devices used there. By learning about the associated tasks and activities and their relevant aspects, participants will be able to understand the requirements for medical devices from the perspective of a hospital. On completion of the module, graduates will have basic knowledge of medical technology planning, procurement and the operation of medical devices in a healthcare facility. Graduates will be able to make decisions on the targeted application of medical technology in the hospital environment. and the Course Content: Functionality and organisation of hospitals - Medical technology planning - Procurement of Medical devices - Operation of Medical devices - Medical IT: networking and information security

For the module with the Module Title: Technology-oriented company foundation, the Learning Outcomes: Graduates of this module learn the basics and requirements for a successful business start-up in the technology sector using case studies from the field of medical technology. Against the background of a possible future business start-up, students will be able to make fundamental assessments of technological ideas and innovations. Using case studies, they learn the essential prerequisites and conditions for a successful business start-up as well as the implementation of product ideas and their marketing. and the Course Content: Preparation of the start-up Personal requirements, opportunities and risks, brainstorming, market analysis, content and design of a business plan, legal aspects I, financing I, start-up team, location, etc. Founding, company structure and development Network, company structure, company strategy, QMS/QMH, employees and management, R&D, accounting and controlling, sales & marketing, legal aspects II, financing II Growth and exit option Financing through venture capital and IPO, managers and investors/partners/shareholders, exit scenarios: Company sale and strategic partnership Modulformblatt_VL_Desi.doc The second part, which follows in the summer semester and contains practical content, takes place partly as a block course and focuses on individual topics in greater depth (including specialist lectures on the topics of business plan, law, marketing, sales, accounting, QMS, financing and funding).

For the module with the Module Title: Testing and approval of medical devices, the Learning Outcomes: Students have practical knowledge of the conformity assessment of medical devices and the tests required in this context at testing institutes or in their own laboratory. They have basic knowledge of the procedure for standardisation and the introduction of a quality management system. They have the ability to familiarise themselves with new contexts, to structure and visualise them in an understandable way and to present the content they have acquired to a specialist audience. By applying their knowledge within a project in cooperation with a medical device manufacturer in the summer semester, they will be familiar with processes from everyday life in industry. and the Course Content: Presentation and moderation, management tools, legal basis for medical devices, Medical Devices Act, Directive 93/42/EEC, standardisation, quality management at medical device manufacturers, technical documentation, risk management, clinical testing and clinical evaluation, international approval of medical devices, statistics in the testing and approval of medical devices, requirements for testing and calibration laboratories, measurement uncertainty considerations and calibration, development of new testing methods, evaluation of the reprocessing of medical devices, testing of active medical devices.

For the module with the Module Title: eHealth fundamentals, the Learning Outcomes: Through active participation, the module should enable students to competently understand the current topic of eHealth and, building on their basic understanding of the topic, to actively work on current technical issues in the subject area. Students who complete the course will be able to differentiate between the subject area of eHealth and related terms and categorise them scientifically. They will gain an insight into the industry with its technical and economic characteristics. They will also understand the necessity of the interaction of IT systems in the healthcare sector and the resulting opportunities. The current and planned future utilisation of IT systems can be recorded, understood and evaluated; this applies in particular to the areas of institutional IT in the healthcare sector (hospitals and doctors' surgeries), the planned telematics infrastructure and the use of mobile devices (mHealth). Examples and group work relating to the industrial and service sectors from the subject area are used to illustrate the content covered and apply it to practical, concrete issues. In addition, current issues relating to this topic are explored in greater depth in application, modelling and homework assignments. and the Course Content: The content of the lecture can be divided into four broad blocks. Firstly, the necessary terms in the field of eHealth and related topics are defined and put in relation to each other. In addition, the German healthcare system is characterised with its players, tasks and processes. The basics of information management in the (German) healthcare system are then discussed. These include electronic communication (e.g. eDoctor's letter, eReferral) and documentation (e.g. ePatient file) as well as legal requirements regarding, for example, electronic billing of services. Furthermore, the telematics infrastructure in general and IT systems of participating players in particular (e.g. hospitals) will be discussed here. Information management concepts are presented in order to understand system architectures and application landscapes of the organisations and networks involved. This includes software architecture and design, as well as modularisation and interfaces in particular. Furthermore, methods and techniques for controlling these architectures (e.g. EAM, BPM etc.) are also discussed. In addition, an understanding of the legal foundations of communication and data protection is to be created. Fundamental aspects of data protection, data security and data integrity are discussed in context. Finally, economic characteristics of the eHealth segment will be presented, focussing on healthcare markets, drivers and barriers to innovation and market forecasts. In particular, the mHealth segment with its relation to the consumer and trend topics (e.g. quantified self, wearables, etc.) will be addressed here. Presentations by cooperation partners will provide a practical reference and emphasise the importance of the topic. 1. eHealth basics: terms and definitions 2. information management in the healthcare sector 3. architecture concepts of information systems in the healthcare sector 4. application areas and business models of eHealth

For the module with the Module Title: Development methods for sustainable products, the Learning Outcomes: Technical products influence their environment beyond their core functionality. Sustainable products take ecological and social aspects into account in all phases of the life cycle. The course teaches methods with which impacts can be assessed and taken into account in the design. These methods should not only be learnt, but also critically reflected upon and discussed. After successfully completing the module, students will have knowledge of - fundamentals of sustainability - methods of technology assessment - methods of requirements analysis - more sustainable design methods - analysis of material and energy flows in the product life cycle - methods of life cycle assessment Skills: Students... - apply selected methods independently. - evaluate technology and scrutinise it critically. - develop and reflect on their own solutions Competences: - Selection and understanding of methods - Problem-solving skills - Holistic consideration and evaluation of products and the Course Content: Lecture: - Fundamentals of sustainability: spatial and temporal levels, strong and weak sustainability, values and guiding principles - TING-D, pillars of sustainability, costs, pre- and post-care principle - Phases of the product life cycle and product development process - Technology assessment according to VDI 3780 and other tools - Requirements analysis with a focus on social and ecological requirements - Design methods with a focus on Eco Design - Working world of engineersX, Corporate Social Responsibility and Sustainable Development Goals - Energy and materials: Life cycle assessment and material/energy flow analyses In the exercise and the project task, the blocks of topics dealt with theoretically in the lecture are applied practically, or critically scrutinised with the help of relevant literature. The methods explained in the lecture are applied.

For the module with the Module Title: Numerical Thermo- and Fluid Dynamics - Fundamentals (CFD1), the Learning Outcomes: The aim is to familiarise students with the basics of approximation and solution techniques for the fluid mechanical balance equations. Various techniques for deriving finite differences and for time integration are presented. In comparison, finite volume methods are explained in various realisations. By programming a solver for the numerical simulation of both stationary and unsteady simple flow problems, the theoretical knowledge will be successively put into practice. and the Course Content: Processing of fluid mechanical problems using numerical methods, finite volume methods for approximating the Euler and shallow water equations, Riemann problems and Riemann solvers, methods for numerical flow determination, Godunov methods, implementation of physical boundary conditions for CFD problems, numerical time integration and finite difference methods, successive programming of a flow solver, flow visualisation.

For the module with the Module Title: Oil-hydraulic drives and control systems, the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the module, students will have: knowledge of - about hydrostatic and hydrodynamic systems - about the structure of basic hydrostatic components, such as pumps, motors and valves - about sensors, actuators and control technology in hydrostatic systems - about exemplary applications Skills: - of the system-oriented problem-solving process - to develop and dimension hydrostatic systems Competences: - to solve complex, mechatronic development tasks taking hydrostatic systems into account - to assess hydrostatic drive and control systems taking ecological, economic, technical and social aspects into account and the Course Content: 1. fundamentals of hydrostatics, hydrodynamics and pneumatics 2. hydraulic fluids 3. basic components of hydraulic systems, such as pumps, motors, valves, etc. 4. control and regulation of fluid power drives 5. planning and operation of hydrostatic systems as an example of fluid power systems 6. application examples from automotive engineering and mechanical engineering 7. modelling and simulation of fluid power components and systems

For the module with the Module Title: Fundamentals of industrial information technology, the Learning Outcomes: Students learn to assess the potentials and techniques of information technology solutions in the industrial environment and to utilise the solutions in a goal-oriented manner. After successfully completing the module, students will have the following knowledge: - Information technology support of product development processes - Information technology support of production control - Cooperation in development co-operation - Interaction of the system landscape in product development processes Skills: - Application of specific application possibilities of basic information technology to solve engineering problems - Implementation of methods for company-wide integration of information technology systems along the value chain Competences: - Ability to select and evaluate different information technology systems in product development processes - Evaluation of the efficiency of individual systems and their interaction in the system landscape of companies - Understanding and ability to develop information models for an application area and the Course Content: Lectures: - Project management and development methodology - CAx techniques and product data management - Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) - Networks and Enterprise Application Integration (EAI) - Communication technology and knowledge management Exercises: - Project and process plans, system landscape in development processes - Basic functions of CAD systems, design of individual parts and assemblies - Basic functions and application of a product data management system - Organisation of procurement processes in an ERP system

For the module with the Module Title: Physical chemistry in the process sciences, the Learning Outcomes: The students should: - Gain knowledge of the basic principles of thermodynamics, the behaviour of pure substances and mixtures and the kinetics of chemical reactions. - Be able to assess and accompany fundamental processes through the abstract thinking they have learnt in physical models. - Be able to apply the mathematical knowledge required for modelling physical effects. - Be able to solve application tasks independently. The course teaches: 60 % knowledge & understanding, 40 % analysis & methodology and the Course Content: Working methods of thermodynamics - Basic concepts: systems, phase, equilibrium, chemical reaction, processes, states, state variables and process variables - Properties of gases: ideal gases, real gases - Main laws of thermodynamics and calculation of changes of state - Pure substance systems: States of aggregation, phase transitions, phase diagrams, phase rule - Behaviour of mixtures: binary and ternary mixtures, description of phase equilibria and their technical applications (VLE, LLE, SLE) - Chemical reactions: Basic concepts, thermochemistry, chemical equilibrium, reaction enthalpy, reaction entropy, Hess's theorem, van`'t Hoff's reaction isobars, Gibbs-Helmholtz equation, equilibrium constant, reaction running number - Reaction kinetics: rate laws, reaction order, half-life, kinetic analysis of experimental data, complex reactions, catalysis - Interfacial phenomena

For the module with the Module Title: Energy, momentum and mass transport IC (6 CP), the Learning Outcomes: Students should: - have a basic understanding of all thermodynamic, process engineering or energy-related heat and mass transfer processes, - understand and be able to estimate processes in heat and mass transfer and their significance in nature and technology and be able to develop models for this, - also be able to work out independent solutions, in particular by setting up and solving the underlying differential equations. The course teaches: 80 % knowledge & understanding, 20 % analysis & methodology and the Course Content: - Physical quantities, balancing; basic laws: Fourier, Fick, heat/substance transfer and passage, Planck (radiation); heat exchangers; - methods for solving differential equations

For the module with the Module Title: Gender and Organization (MA-BIWI 7b) (Gender and Organization), the Learning Outcomes: Students gain a sound overview of interdisciplinary gender studies and in-depth knowledge of gender-related organisational research. After completing the module, students will be able to: - name theories and concepts for interpreting and explaining gender differences and explain their similarities and differences. - discuss the relevance of gender difference for the structuring of social reality and reflect on it with regard to processes of social change. - situate the concept of organisation historically and justify the significance of organisations for the structuring of social processes. 
 - name and classify different approaches to gender research in the field of organisational research. - identify different instruments and measures of organisational gender equality policy, name their theoretical premises and evaluate them. - transfer knowledge of gender and organisational theory to practice in educational institutions, analyse field-specific problems and discuss corresponding options for action. - familiarise themselves independently in small groups with in-depth questions and prepare and present the results in a professional manner. - act as a gender-reflective counsellor - apply reflective knowledge with regard to gender constructions and gender relations and the Course Content: The aim of this module is to understand the ways in which ‘gender’ can be understood as a complex, historically produced construct that essentially structures social realities and is itself structured by knowledge, institutions and social and cultural practices. In particular, the question of the extent to which organisations and organisational units must be regarded as social entities structured by gender or as active ‘constructors’ of gender will be addressed. To this end, organisational structures and manifestations of the processes of ‘doing gender’ as well as internal organisational discourses on the legitimation or de-legitimation of gender differences and inequalities and their structural anchoring are empirically examined and analysed. The question is whether and how the respective organisational types and units are linked to the gender differences and inequalities produced outside the organisation, and how internal organisational processes in turn affect external gender orders. Based on current ways of addressing gender (such as gender mainstreaming and controlling, diversity, work-life balance), the scope for intervention and competencies for organisational development processes are discussed and the basics of competencies are taught.

For the module with the Module Title: Global Climate and SDG Engagement I, the Learning Outcomes: Upon completing the course, students will be able to: - Plan projects in international, intercultural and transdisciplinary teams to fulfill the needs of local communities in the partner countries of the network using renewable energy or other sustainable technologies; - Communicate interculturally especially with partners in the Global South and to reflect on this communication; - Network with different partners (local communities, cooperatives, business, administration); - Plan their project work as a service-learning project, know all necessary aspects of this concept and realize a certain number of service elements contributing to the success of the project for the partner community and environmental aspects; - Plan and work in social business project and know the characteristics of social business; - Contribute to climate and SDGs by local and common international climate action through CO2compensation; - Reflect on climate justice and SDGs allowing a potential change of behavior to reduce individual and collective negative impact on climate, environment, and global justice; - Use different methods to collect data for analyzing the needs of the community partner; - Have an overview about different technologies and background information necessary to develop sustainable community-based projects; - Conduct literature research and analyses of prior projects in the area and the sociocultural context to improve their own project work; and - Use English as a common language for international scientific and project work. and the Course Content: Das integrierte Modul bietet: - internationale hybride Workshops von Dozenten aller Partnerländer zu Technologien und Hintergrundinformationen, die für die Entwicklung nachhaltiger gemeindebasierter Projekte erforderlich sind, z. B. interkulturelle Kommunikation, PV-Schulung, CO2-Kompensation, Haushaltsbiogasanlagen, sauberes Kochen, Biogas, Social Business; - internationale studentische hybride Arbeitsgruppen, die CO2-Kompensationsprojekte für Klima und SDGs entwickeln und dabei die Bedürfnisse der lokalen Partnergemeinden zusammen mit den Partner-NGOs angehen; - praktische Service-Elemente, die zum Erfolg des Projekts für die Partnergemeinde und zu den Klimaschutzmaßnahmen beitragen (einschließlich z. B., Schulungen in Schulen, Fundraising-Veranstaltungen, Aktivitäten in den Bereichen Abfallwirtschaft, biologischer Gartenbau, Baumpflanzungen); und - Forschungs- und Innovationsmöglichkeiten zur Vertiefung der Entwicklung und Anwendung nachhaltiger Technologien und Methoden.

For the module with the Module Title: Environmental and resource economics, the Learning Outcomes: In der Veranstaltung werden die Konzepte der modernen Umweltökonomie vermittelt und Bezüge zu anderen volkswirtschaftlichen Veranstaltungen hergestellt. Des Weiteren werden diese theoretischen Kenntnisse durch ihre Anwendung auf aktuelle Umweltprobleme verdeutlicht. Im Einzelnen deckt die Veranstaltung folgende Gebiete ab: - Das Grundproblem der Umweltökonomie (Marktversagen aufgrund von Externalitäten und öffentlichen Gütern), - Ziele der Umweltpolitik (wohlfahrtsökonomische Betrachtung, Einführung in die Ökonomie erschöpflicher und erneuerbarer Ressourcen) - Instrumente der Umweltpolitik (Steuern, Auflagen, Zertifikate, Verhandlungen, Haftungsrecht) - Mikroökonomische Prognose der Wirkung von Umweltpolitik An Methoden werden Grundlagen der Politikanalyse, die Entscheidungstheorie bei statischen und dynamischen Problemen sowie die Integration technisch/naturwissenschaftlicher und ökonomischer Modelle gelehrt. and the Course Content: The course teaches the concepts of modern environmental economics and establishes links to other economics courses. Furthermore, this theoretical knowledge is illustrated by applying it to current environmental problems. In detail, the course covers the following areas: - The basic problem of environmental economics (market failure due to externalities and public goods), - Objectives of environmental policy (welfare economics, introduction to the economics of exhaustible and renewable resources) - Instruments of environmental policy (taxes, regulations, certificates, negotiations, liability law) - Microeconomic forecasting of the effects of environmental policy The methods taught include the basics of policy analysis, decision theory for static and dynamic problems and the integration of technical/natural science and economic models.

For the module with the Module Title: Climate neutrality and decarbonisation, the Learning Outcomes: After the successful completion of the module the students: - know sectors contributing to GHG emissions and possible reduction potentials - be proficient in determining relevant mitigation measures specific for a certain sector or product - are able to determine the reduction potential of mitigation measures - be able to provide decision support for organizations and policy regarding which mitigation measures to select in line with current political targets - know the trade-offs of these measures with other sustainability aspects - have the ability to select compensation measures that are in line with current scientific research as well as supported by political instruments The module´s qualification profile is: 40% knowledge and understanding, 20% development and design, 20% research and evaluation, 20% application and practice and the Course Content: - Decarbonisation szenarios - Mitigation measures, technologies, and potentials of different sectors such as mobility, agriculture, energy, etc. - Bioeconomy - Green electricity - Green hydrogen - Trade-offs of climate change and other sustainability aspects - NET Compensation measures such as forestation and carbon capture and storage and associated potentials - Carbon accounting like Product Carbon Footprint and Greenhouse Gas Protocol - Laws and regulations supporting decarbonization and climate neutrality - Pricing instruments - Standards and guidelines addressing decarbonization and climate neutrality

For the module with the Module Title: Introduction to landscape planning and environmental assessment, the Learning Outcomes: Students gain knowledge of key environmental issues and challenges of the 21st century (e.g. urbanisation, soil degradation, loss of biodiversity, climate change, energy) and their consequences for the ecosystem as well as the instruments of landscape planning and environmental assessment. Students learn about the scope, objectives, content, procedures and interrelationships of the main instruments under the Federal Nature Conservation Act and the Environmental Impact Assessment Act (landscape planning, protected areas, environmental impact assessment, strategic environmental assessment, impact regulation, FFH impact assessment and special species protection assessment) and can relate these to overall spatial planning and spatially effective sectoral planning. 
In addition, this enables students to familiarise themselves with the structure and work steps of the specialist documents of the environmental assessment, to be able to prepare the relevant documents after further specialisation in the module ‘Practice of landscape planning and environmental assessment’, and to understand what distinguishes the role of environmental planners from that of expert assessors for individual environmental assets. Overall, students recognise how the expert reports in the environmental assessment are prepared in accordance with legal, technical and practical requirements and what they can achieve in practice. Students will also be able to categorise the instruments within the framework of nature conservation, environmental protection and sustainable development and identify the differences between them. They will also become aware of the conceptual vagueness of the basic terms of the discipline (nature, environment, landscape) and the associated need to address these in the respective planning process. and the Course Content: The lecture series ‘Environmental Issues of the 21st Century’ deals with key challenges from the perspective of the various disciplines of ecology and planning (and possibly landscape architecture), which they face in the 21st century and which graduates of the programme should contribute to overcoming. Examples include urbanisation, soil degradation, loss of biodiversity, climate change and a sustainable energy supply. In this way, introductory ‘topics’ are named and taught for which the instruments of landscape planning and environmental assessment are relevant. The course ‘Introduction to Landscape Planning and Environmental Assessment I’ aims to provide an overview of the instruments of landscape planning and environmental assessment in their entirety (protected areas, landscape planning, environmental impact assessment, strategic environmental assessment, impact regulation, FFH impact assessment, special species protection assessment), including their relationship to spatial and urban land-use planning and selected spatially relevant sectoral planning. The instruments and associated plans are explained on the basis of case studies, which provides an initial familiarisation with methods and procedures, which is deepened in the module ‘Practice of Landscape Planning and Environmental Assessment’. The course ‘Introduction to Landscape Planning and Environmental Assessment II’ firstly deepens knowledge of the instruments of environmental assessment and secondly introduces basic terms and concepts of the discipline. As part of the in-depth study of environmental assessment instruments, students will familiarise themselves with the core of the relevant professional field. The individual steps involved in preparing the integrating expert reports are presented and supported with exercises: - Environmental reports (of the strategic environmental assessment) include, among other things, the presentation of the environmental protection objectives applicable to the plan or programme, - EIA reports (of the environmental impact assessment) deal with, among other things, the expected environmental impacts of a project and planned measures to reduce the occurrence of adverse environmental impacts, en - Landscape conservation plans (for nature conservation intervention regulation) include, among other things, the planning of compensation and mitigation measures, en - Environmental impact assessment reports (of the environmental impact assessment) deal with, among other things, the planning of compensation and mitigation measures, en Specialist reports (for the FFH impact assessment and species protection assessment, saP) focus on determining whether projects or plans are likely to have a significant impact on an FFH area or violate the prohibitions in the case of protected species). In addition, there are examples of more recent fields of activity such as impact studies with regard to the requirements of the EU Water Framework Directive. As part of the presentation of basic terms and concepts, the planning instruments mentioned are categorised in the fields of nature conservation and environmental protection as well as the concept of sustainable development. The terms nature, environment and landscape, which are fundamental to the discipline, are introduced and discussed. In addition, possible contributions of landscape planning to current environmental issues, e.g. climate change and its effects, can be presented.

For the module with the Module Title: The Economics of Climate Change, the Learning Outcomes: The Economics of Climate Change is an introductory course into the economic assessment of climate change impacts and optimal mitigation and adaptation response. Welfare-economic concepts such as cost-benefit analysis, (inter-generational) discounting, non-market valuation, and different concepts of social welfare are applied to understand the impacts of climate change and climate change mitigation on long-term welfare and growth. Since these concepts can be applied to many public policy problems, the course is also an introduction into intertemporal welfare theory and public economics. The lecture provides reasoning, theory, and the narrative. The tutorial provides analytical concepts, formal models, and mathematical techniques. and the Course Content: Starting from the perspective of a social planner, we provide a systematic overview of the relevant issues in climate change policy. This includes, inter alia: -Physics of climate change: global warming, radiative forcing, greenhouse gases, feedbacks, carbon cycle, uncertainties and projections -Climate change impacts on biological and human systems, vulnerability, adaptive capacity, tipping points -Social cost-benefit analysis: market and non-market valuation of impacts, discounting and its ethical implications for inter- and intragenerational equity; uncertainty, Social Cost of Carbon -Stock pollutants: the atmosphere as a limited disposal space for greenhouse gases -Social welfare: concepts of social welfare, equity and fairness, social welfare functions, approaches to measure welfare in a broader sense -Growth: the interrelation between climate change, economic development and growth; theories of economic growth, Hotelling’s rule -Mitigation options in different sectors, including land and bioenergy, cities and transport, power generation, negative emissions, geoengineering and variable renewables

For the module with the Module Title: Inequality and the Environment, the Learning Outcomes: Environmental change is everywhere. But not everyone is impacted in the same way. Whether you are rich or poor, young or old, from the global north or the global south, climate and environmental change have different implications. Poorer people in industrialized countries experience a disproportionate cost of climate policy. Younger people have less responsibility for environmental degradation, but will bear it longer. People from the global south generally have a lower carbon footprint but are likely to suffer greater damage from climate change. The key question is how to reconcile the goals of reducing inequalities and protecting the environment. Are there “win-win” policies? If so, what are the obstacles to their implementation? The students learn how to use academic work on inequality to analyze environmental policies. and the Course Content: The seminar analyzes the challenges posed by economic and social inequalities in the context of global environmental change. It addresses several dimensions of inequality such as income, wealth, race, and gender. The link between inequality and the environment is examined along many perspectives, including economic theory, political science, climate science, and environmental justice. Among other topics, the seminar investigates if income inequality harms the environment and hinders the implementation of appropriate public policies. The overlap between distributive effects of environmental change and underlying inequalities is also discussed, together with the implications for the design of fair policies. Finally, debates on historical responsibility and inter-generational equity are introduced in the context of global climate action.

For the module with the Module Title: Waste and resource management, the Learning Outcomes: The students should: - develop a basic understanding of material and energy flows in selected industrial sectors as well as waste generation in production processes and private households, - know and be able to describe processes and process technologies for the treatment of industrial and municipal waste as well as their products, - know the basic legal framework conditions for waste prevention and treatment and place them in an environmental policy context, - master the technical and methodological fundamentals of the field of recycling management and be able to transfer this knowledge to practice, - strengthen the ability to research literature and data, visualise process balances, manage literature data and engage in scientific discussion (also in English if necessary), - develop the ability to write and write down demonstrate the ability to work both in a team and independently and to take on responsibility. The course teaches: 30 % knowledge & understanding, 40 % analysis & methodology, 0 % development & design, 20 % research & evaluation, 10 % social skills and the Course Content: Waste management - Legal basics; - Definition and classification of waste - Generation and characteristics of municipal waste; - Waste collection and logistics; - Recycling and disposal processes Material flow & resource management - Scientific, methodological and technical basics (material flow analysis, technical representation of processes, evaluation of resource efficiency) - Consideration of selected material flows from various areas of need (e.g. housing, nutrition, lifestyle and mobility) - Overview of selected production processes - Best available technology (examples from selected sectors) Consideration of selected material flows from various areas of need (e.g. housing, nutrition, lifestyle and mobility) - Overview of selected production processes - Best available technology (examples from selected sectors)

For the module with the Module Title: Urban design project II, the Learning Outcomes: Students are able to independently apply the appropriate design, communication and presentation methods for the project and develop them into a coherent overall concept. Students also recognise gender references and sustainability aspects in the task of the design project and take these into account appropriately in their work. The module teaches: Professional competence 50% Methodological competence 20% System competence 20% Social competence 10%. and the Course Content: Depending on the subject area, the topic of the design is redefined each semester. In addition to the basic research, the development of a conceptual strategy and the design, the project will focus on the development of design techniques, work concepts and organisational models. Furthermore, an aspect of the design determined by the specialisation will be examined in more detail and deepened through a project-integrated course (PIV). This may be a theoretical, technical, historical, architectural, artistic or other specialisation. It must be offered in co-operation with another subject area. Justified exceptions are possible.

For the module with the Module Title: Urban/Nature Sketching Advanced, the Learning Outcomes: In-depth knowledge of perspective rules and graphic effects for depth and volume (textures and details) - Knowledge and use of different drawing and colour materials - Perfection of working techniques under different conditions (working at varying speeds and under different conditions) - Development of an own graphic language and search for style and graphic identity and the Course Content: The course focuses on the analogue drawing of real urban and natural motifs: ‘urban/nature sketching’. Drawing techniques, knowledge of materials and examples from the rich world of illustration are taught. Various techniques and graphic languages will be tried out with the help of exercises, and gradually your own style can be found and developed. The special thing about this seminar is that we will work directly on the motif outdoors as much as possible.

For the module with the Module Title: Gender Studies, the Learning Outcomes: Die Studierenden sollen in der Lage sein, die Inhalte und Methoden der Landschafts- und Umweltplanung auf landschaftsarchitektonische Fragestellungen anzuwenden und umzusetzen. Das Modul vermittelt vor allem: Fachkompetenz 50%; Methodenkompetenz 20%; Systemkompetenz 20%; Sozialkompetenz 10%. and the Course Content: Contrary to everyday experience that gender (gender difference) is a “natural” given, gender studies understand “gender” as a complex, historically produced construct that essentially structures social, cultural, linguistic, technological, media and “natural” realities as well as scientific knowledge and scientific practice and that is itself structured by knowledge and social, cultural and technical practices. Accordingly, in addition to teaching the basics of gender theory, the focus of teaching is on the investigation of gendering processes in all fields of social, technical, scientific, cultural and individual realities.

For the module with the Module Title: TU Berlin for Future - the lecture series on climate protection, part 1, the Learning Outcomes: Students should a) gain an insight into climate research in various disciplines at TU Berlin, b) gain an overview of the need and scope for action for effective climate protection strategies and c) learn to assess the potential and risks associated with various climate protection measures. The course mainly teaches: 50% knowledge and understanding, 15% research and evaluation, 20% reflection and argumentation, 15% social skills. and the Course Content: The event is organized by Prof. Dr. Dr. Martina Schäfer (ZTG), Prof. Dr. Ulf Schrader (ALÖNK), Dr. Viola Muster (ALÖNK), Dr. Gabriele Wendorf (ZTG) and the student association Fridays For Future at TU Berlin.
