The planned lectures in the lecture series include contributions from various specialist areas that reflect the range of climate research at TU Berlin from an engineering, natural and social science perspective. For various fields of action, such as energy supply, mobility, everyday consumption, agriculture, construction and housing, it will be presented which research questions relevant to climate protection are dealt with in the respective subject areas and which scientific findings are available. Social trends such as globalization, digitalization and urbanization are also taken into account. In addition to an insight into the respective state of knowledge, the need and scope for action with regard to effective climate protection strategies are presented. In an exchange with the students, the groups of actors responsible for the implementation of the respective measures and the political and structural framework required for this are worked out. Furthermore, the potentials, but also the risks of the respective climate protection strategies (undesired side effects, such as different burdens on different population groups or with regard to other environmental goals) are reflected upon. As a result, students should gain an impression of the complexity of the topic of climate protection and the complexity of effective climate protection strategies. In addition to a technical lecture, interactive elements are used in the course and sufficient time is planned for a moderated discussion.

For the module with the Module Title: Social inequality, the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the module, students will not only have in-depth knowledge of social inequality, global inequality and social structure analysis, but will also be able to apply this knowledge discursively to case studies. The module predominantly teaches professional competence = 65% methodological competence = 5% system competence 15% social competence 15% and the Course Content: The module is dedicated to current theoretical and empirical findings on social inequality, global inequality and social structure analysis. Individual dimensions of social inequality (e.g. “class”, “citizenship”, “race”/“ethnicity”/“migration”, “age”, “health”/“disability” or “gender”) are examined in their intersectionality with other dimensions of social inequality. In addition, the interaction of social inequality with various social, economic, political, technical and/or ecological fields of social action is analyzed. Finally, the module provides theoretical background knowledge for their analytical inclusion. The module can be taken up to 10 times. The field of research is developing very dynamically. It therefore makes sense to choose individual topics depending on the current state of research and specific interests. 
Each student therefore chooses a course from a pool of courses assigned to the module. The exact topics and course titles may therefore vary. Topics covered in individual seminars could be - as the following exemplary course titles show - for example: Social Inequality 1: Class 1 Social Inequality 2: Class 2 Social Inequality 3: Space Social Inequality 4: Citizenship, Race, Ethnicity and Migration 1 Social Inequality 5: Citizenship, Race, Ethnicity and Migration 1 Social Inequality 6: Time and Social Processes Social Inequality 7: Age and Lifecourse Social Inequality 8: Health and Disability Social Inequality 9: Gender 1 Social Inequality 10: Gender 2

For the module with the Module Title: Food System Change, the Learning Outcomes: After successfully completing the module, students will be able to - work on practical and scientific topics from the field of energy technology, especially renewable energies in an ecological and social context in a team-oriented and independent manner - develop a question that penetrates the topic - research suitable literature - apply both engineering and social science methods (e.g. plant design, simulations or qualitative social research approaches) to design practice-oriented planning processes from the energy and environmental sector in independent and team-oriented group work and implement them in functional models. and the Course Content: The aim is to examine a wide range of issues relating to food, agriculture, the environment and society, both on a theoretical and practical level. The aim is not only to uncover the causes of problems, but also to develop concrete steps towards a more sustainable and fairer food system. The focus is on team-oriented work on the technical, social and ecological aspects of various practical and science-oriented topics. The project workshop deals with the following topics, among others - the influence of animal feed exports and (new) genetic engineering technologies on the climate and food security - the impact of European meat exports on local agriculture in the global South - connections and interactions between agriculture economic power of large agribusinesses and alternative farming models such as SoLaWi - state of agri-PV research on effects on soils, plant growth, microclimate, land use and business management - ecological practices in agriculture such as humus culture, permaculture, indigenous knowledge - practical planning and installation of an agri-PV system

For the module with the Module Title: Advances in thermal and non-thermal food preservation, the Learning Outcomes: The students should: - have a sound knowledge of flow and thermal engineering issues, - be able to judge the microbiological safety of a food product on the basis of specific process parameters, - have acquired extensive knowledge in the field of thermal and non-thermal food preservation processes. The course teaches: 20% knowledge & understanding 40% development & design 40% application & practice and the Course Content: - Flow fundamentals - Thermal fundamentals - Kinetic and mathematical fundamentals - Pressure and temperature dependencies - Physiology and fitness of microorganisms - Pasteurization and sterilization - Freezing processes - Extraction processes - High-pressure homogenization - Research subject and outlook Focus on kinetics, transformation reactions, mechanisms and modelling techniques

For the module with the Module Title: Global Health, the Learning Outcomes: The course is designed to provide students with an understanding of how various global issues impact health, health policy, health care, and social and economic change. Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to understand the many interrelated determinants that impact global health and disease on a scale ranging from the individual to society as a whole. These include politics, globalisation, sustainability, finance, equity, ethics, human rights, socio-cultural issues and climate change. Students will have gained insights into emerging diseases, the key determinants of global diseases and the interplay between biomedical, global and social processes that play a role in major global diseases. They will understand the different regulations, norms, actors, organisations and institutions involved at global, national, regional and local levels and be aware of the different health systems and contexts in which they operate. They will be able to discuss the challenges, opportunities and areas of tension associated with the increasing mobility of healthcare personnel and digitalisation. In addition, they will be able to critically assess (global) health policy measures, the increasing complexity of global health challenges and the performance of health systems at various levels. Various practical examples and group work help to deepen the acquired knowledge. The practice-orientated lectures and group work throughout the semester help students to illustrate and apply the course content. and the Course Content: Global health encompasses knowledge and perspectives from the fields of public health, medicine, epidemiology, health economics, behavioral sciences, environmental sciences, and anthropology, to name a few. This course aims to provide a foundational understanding of the ever-evolving field of global health, its disciplines, principles, actors, challenges and opportunities. The first part of the course starts with some basics and focuses on the global burden of disease (etiology) and the determinants of health - especially in relation to disadvantaged populations. In addition, students will become familiar with the scientific discussion on globalization processes and their impact on people's access to health care as well as the health problems resulting from climate change. We will also look at the global health agenda and the goals of global health care in different areas. The third part focuses on human rights, the impact on health (in)equality and equity and how social conditions can influence health and health inequalities. The fourth block deals with global health policy and the system as a whole, including considerations of 'good governance'. It will address issues of interplay between key actors and institutions involved in health at the global level (WHO, World Health Council, etc.), at the national level (public, private, NGO, etc.) and at the local level (civil society, patients, communities, etc.). It will show how this interplay determines and influences the functioning of health systems, their financing and issues of accountability. The course concludes with a consideration of the complex relationships between global health and technological innovation, the role of mobility of professionals and the impact on social, political and economic change.

For the module with the Module Title: Global quality management and sustainable corporate governance, the Learning Outcomes: The globalisation of markets and the resulting changes in customer and competitor behaviour have led to many globally active companies, as socio-technical systems, being confronted with a significant increase in complexity in the market environment and within the company itself. The increase in complexity extends not only to market differentiation, products, processes and services, but also to the integration of different cultures and world views within the company. As a result, quality management in globally active companies is also confronted with new challenges as to how the quality promises made to customers can be kept worldwide. The lecture Global Quality Management explains which extended tasks global quality management will have to take on in the future, especially in the areas of product development, product manufacturing and product maintenance. It focuses in particular on the tension between centralised and decentralised responsibility for quality, and highlights possible solutions, taking into account the different cultural circumstances. This gives students a broader understanding of global quality management based on the challenges faced by international companies today. and the Course Content: After a brief introduction, the lecture presents the different global market strategies and the target figures that apply to every company, such as liquidity, turnover, return on investment, etc., and illustrates them using a globally active company in the plant engineering sector. The focus is on the tension between the domestic market and international market development, whereby the fundamental connection between a global understanding of quality and quality management as a prerequisite for global market success is discussed. The objectives and success factors for global quality management are presented on the basis of globally networked corporate structures using practical examples of product development, product manufacture and product maintenance. In this context, corporate management means global interface and intercultural change management, as the fulfillment of a uniform quality standard must be guaranteed despite all global heterogeneity. Lecture/exercise materials and further information are provided on the ISIS platform.

For the module with the Module Title: EduLab: Teaching, learning, education, the Learning Outcomes: Students will be familiar with selected approaches and findings from learning psychology, specifically cognitive, motivational and emotional research on teaching and learning, and will be able to categorise these with regard to self-regulated learning and learning with digital media. They can apply these approaches to reflect on their own learning experiences and learning processes. With support, students can develop, carry out, analyse and present a question for a small empirical project on this topic. Students know basic terms and procedures for quantitative empirical educational research and can apply the questionnaire research method in the context of the project. and the Course Content: In the project lab, we examine various aspects of learning and teaching and look at current theories and findings in psychology: Information processing, memory, knowledge and forgetting (cognition), Types of motivation in learning, the role of emotions in learning, learning with digital media, Approaches to promoting learning (e.g. at university)
We also learn about the ‘questionnaire’ research method: Planning, design and procedures of quantitative educational research, Data collection, data analysis and interpretation of questionnaire surveys 
(e.g. descriptive statistics)
